question.title: Is it possible to bypass parent Interceptor invocation in Java EE?
question.body:
I'm working on a Java EE application where I have created a custom interceptor that extends an existing parent interceptor. My goal is to conditionally skip the invocation of the parent interceptor's logic based on certain conditions. The parent interceptor comes from a framework and cant be modified.

Simplified version of my interceptor setup:

import jakarta.annotation.Priority;
import jakarta.interceptor.AroundInvoke;
import jakarta.interceptor.Interceptor;
import jakarta.interceptor.InvocationContext;

@Interceptor
@Priority(Interceptor.Priority.APPLICATION - 1)
public class CustomInterceptor extends ParentInterceptor {

    @Override
    @AroundInvoke
    public Object checkSecurity(InvocationContext ctx) throws Exception {
        // Custom logic to determine whether to skip the parent interceptor
        if (shouldSkip()) {
            return ctx.proceed(); // This still calls the parent intercptor
        }
        // Call the parent interceptor's logic if not skipping
        return super.checkSecurity(ctx);
    }

    private boolean shouldSkip() {
        return true; // Example condition
    }
}

@Interceptor
@Priority(Interceptor.Priority.APPLICATION) // Default priority
public class ParentInterceptor {
    @AroundInvoke
    public Object checkSecurity(InvocationContext ctx) throws Exception {
        // Logic for the parent interceptor
        return ctx.proceed();
    }
}

Questions:

  1. Is it possible to skip the invocation of the parent interceptor's method (super.checkSecurity(ctx)) in this scenario? If so, how can I achieve this without affecting the execution of other interceptors in the chain?
  2. Are there any best practices or patterns for managing such scenarios in Java EE interceptor chains?

Thanks in advance!

question_comments.body: Is using composition over inheritance (and making sure you are not registering/enabling the ParentInterceptor (in your beans.xml, via annotations or whatever) anywhere) an option?
Side note: The java-ee-7 tag looks wrong, because the code in the question uses Jakarta libraries. See Transition from Java EE to Jakarta EE.

Once an interceptor is bound and in the chain for a method, it will always be called. Your 'parent' interceptor is still called, because it remains in the interceptor chain, not because you created a subclass from it. You have both in the chain, so both will be called. If you make the call to super, the 'parent' is effectively called twice (once from your class, once from the CDI). You would need to completely replace this original intreceptor in the chain if you wanted the ability to skip it entirely. Or in other words: Avoid binding the parent in the first place.
